description.narrative:
The Masarouna programme implements two main pathways of change:
1: Lobby and advocacy with young people for their SRHR The first pathway promotes greater accountability of governments to adhere to international SRHR standards, human rights frameworksand agreements; promotes young people’s active and meaningful involvement in policy agenda-setting and decision-making; and increases public awareness on SRHR, including through media engagement, aiming to create new narratives on SRHR.
2: Strengthening civil society and reinventing civic space A strong civil society can be a mobilizer, an amplifier of voices and a watchdog. With strengthened capacities,CSOs can create a sense of urgency around SRHR to push for sustainable change. CSOs need the spaceto play this political role, which Masarouna aims to reinvent by promoting the political activation and participation of young people and creating and strengthening alternative civic spaces, both online and offline. Working online allows for reaching young people at scale by circumventing gatekeepersand mitigating risks around censorship.
Under this project, and through its theory of change, Oxfam has committed to continue supporting 6 organizations national level- Palestinian human and women's rights organizations. Believing that driving positive impact can be achieved through building national partnerships that focuses on creating spaces for the active engagement of right holders and working together towards holding key stakeholders accountable todrive structural change. Oxfam will continue facilitating strengthening partners capacities, through supporting the organizational and financial capacities of partners throughout the course of the project implementation. Likewise, Oxfam will work towards offering capacity building opportunities to partners in key areas thatwill increase the quality of implementation by linking with national and International expertise (through linking with HQ staff) tobuild their capacities in influencing skills, focusing on International Influencing specifically on the UN Influencing mechanisms, youth active citizenship, women transformative leadership, civic space. Likewise, Oxfam will work on linking the work of partners tointernational level, making use of international events, fora and mechanisms to raise young people and partners voices on SRHR rights. Similarly, Oxfam will facilitate wider alliances through linking with its wide network of partners and coalitions and through the implementation of internationaladvocacy trips to increase CSOs influence on national and international decision makers by linking and building local regional and international alliances for gender sensitive peace and security.

participating-org.narrative:
Oxfam Novib has been active in the Occupied Palestinian Territory/Israel (OPT/I) since 1982 and working with Palestinian refugees in Lebanon since the mid 1980s. It has built up a strong network of relationships with local NGOs and counts among its localcounterparts some of the largest and most professional NGOs in various sectors. It has accompanied these NGOs in their development from ad hoc volunteer groups to sizeable professional institutions with national outreach. At the same time the conceptualisation of the programme has evolved from three country programs in the early 1990s to a program for Palestinians in the Middle East (PME) working withPalestinians in OPT, Israel and Lebanon.
The programme has changed over the years with the establishment of the Palestinian Authority (PA) in the mid-1990s from a focus on support and service provision at a grassroots level and grassroots mobilization, to working towards influencing the establishment of the PA, its lawmaking and supporting building a democratic state # this involved supporting efforts of Palestinian civil society to build the basis for a democratic Palestinian state with room for civil participation, ensuring inclusion of vulnerable groups, refugees and women, and shaping its laws and systems. Oxfam Novib has also supported partners that are working on the provision of humanitarian assistance, response preparedness and conflict transformation. We have also supported partners in the provision of health services, access to quality education and gender justice.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to social and political participation

EO1 Young people and civil society are capacitated to advocate for safe, adequate and inclusive SRHR information and services
KI-6 # CSOs/movements, both women and youth led, capacitated by Masarouna to advocate for safe and adequate SRHR information and services for diverse young people

comment.narrative: A Mutual Capacity Strengthening baseline survey was conducted in 2021, screening seven different capacities under the topic of influencing and awareness raising on SRHR for young people. These are: developing an influencing strategy, youth-led influencing, lobby and/or advocacy on policies and practices, public campaigning, digital campaigning, working with traditional media, and influencing social norms. Digital campaigning stood out as the topic with the most needs. Lobby and/or advocacy on policies and practices, had a majority of organizations indicating a need, and public campaigning and influencing social norms each had about half indicating needs. The topics for which most organizations involved in Masarouna indicated to already having a strong capacity and being eager to support others, are: working with traditional media; developing an influencing strategy; youth-led influencing and public campaigning. (Organisations could express a need, an offer, or both a need and offer on the same topic).

In 2022, capacity strengthening in relation to influencing on SRHR for diverse young people will focus on the needs as expressed by respective organisations involved in Masarouna. These include capacity strengthening on digital campaigning, lobby and/or advocacy on policies and practices, public campaigning and influencing social norms.

description.narrative: KI-6 # CSOs/movements, not women or youth led, capacitated by Masarouna to advocate for safe and adequate SRHR information and services for diverse young people

comment.narrative: A Mutual Capacity Strengthening baseline survey was conducted in 2021, screening seven different capacities under the topic of influencing and awareness raising on SRHR for young people. These are: developing an influencing strategy, youth-led influencing, lobby and/or advocacy on policies and practices, public campaigning, digital campaigning, working with traditional media, and influencing social norms. In 2022, capacity strengthening in relation to influencing on SRHR for diverse young people will focus on the needs as expressed by respective organisations involved in Masarouna. description.narrative: KI-6 # Women led CSOs/movements capacitated by Masarouna to advocate for safe and adequate SRHR information and services for diverse young people

comment.narrative: A Mutual Capacity Strengthening baseline survey was conducted in 2021, screening seven different capacities under the topic of influencing and awareness raising on SRHR for young people. These are: developing an influencing strategy, youth-led influencing, lobby and/or advocacy on policies and practices, public campaigning, digital campaigning, working with traditional media, and influencing social norms. Digital campaigning stood out as the topic with the most needs. Lobby and/or advocacy on policies and practices, had a majority of organizations indicating a need, and public campaigning and influencing social norms each had about half indicating needs. With respect to lobby and/or advocacy, it was also mentioned that it is difficult to advocate for inclusive SRHR policies and that there is a need for alternatives to create inclusive SRHR policies, and hence for enhanced capacities for this. The topics for which most organizations involved in Masarouna indicated to already having a strong capacity and being eager to support others, are: working with traditional media; developing an influencing strategy; youth-led influencing and public campaigning. (Organisations could express a need, an offer, or both a need and offer on the same topic).

In 2021, as a result of the trainings offered by RNW Media, one of the women led organisatons is capacitated to create engaging SRHR content, involve and include media that can be engaged in advocacy and use of data for that advocacy.

In 2022, capacity strengthening in relation to influencing on SRHR for diverse young people will focus on the needs as expressed by respective organisations involved in Masarouna. These include capacity strengthening on digital campaigning, lobby and/or advocacy on policies and practices, public campaigning and influencing social norms.
RNW Media will support one of the women led organisations on digital M&E, including a coaching trajectory focusing on which collecting data should be collected to serve youth needs for advocacy. As a result of this support, the organisation will have strenghtened capacity of using data for advocacy. Also, RNW Media will sensitise the organisation on the use of digital tools (such as the social listening tool) to inform, monitor and evaluate online campaigns and use this for advocacy purposes.

description.narrative: KI-6 # Youth led CSOs/movements capacitated by Masarouna to advocate for safe and adequate SRHR information and services for diverse young people
EO4 CSOs working with young people have increased their organisational capacities and have increased their civic space influencing capacity (online/offline) on SRHR
KI-13 # CSOs/ movements, both women and youth led, supported by Masarouna to strengthen their civic space influencing capacity

comment.narrative: A Mutual Capacity Strengthening baseline survey was conducted in 2021, screening partners' capacities in reclaiming civic space and strengthening partnerships. Most partners expressed a need for capacity strengthening in the following areas: widening (digital) civic space for young people working on SHRH; civic space risk mitigation & protection of staff, partners and people we work with; protection in digital space; and strengthening/broadening partnerships. Most organisations stated already having a strong capacity in shaping positive narratives. (Organisations could express a need, an offer, or both a need and offer on the same topic.)

A capacity building plan will be developed based on the three priorities for capacity building identified by Masarouna partners (safety and well-being, dialogue and consultation, and access to information and public voice ).

description.narrative: KI-13 # CSOs/movements, not women or youth led, supported by Masarouna to strengthen their civic space influencing capacity

comment.narrative: A Mutual Capacity Strengthening baseline survey was conducted in 2021, screening partners' capacities in reclaiming civic space and strengthening partnerships. Most organisations stated already having a strong capacity in shaping positive narratives. (Organisations could express a need, an offer, or both a need and offer on the same topic.)

description.narrative: KI-13 # Women led CSOs/ movements supported by Masarouna to strengthen their civic space influencing capacity

comment.narrative: A Mutual Capacity Strengthening baseline survey was conducted in 2021, screening partners' capacities in reclaiming civic space and strengthening partnerships. Most partners expressed a need for capacity strengthening in the following areas: widening (digital) civic space for young people working on SHRH; civic space risk mitigation & protection of staff, partners and people we work with; protection in digital space; and strengthening/broadening partnerships. Most organisations stated already having a strong capacity in shaping positive narratives. (Organisations could express a need, an offer, or both a need and offer on the same topic.)

A capacity building plan will be developed based on the three priorities for capacity building identified by Masarouna partners (safety and well-being, dialogue and consultation, and access to information and public voice).
RNW Media will strengthen CSOs on several aspects regarding civic cpace influencing, including strengthening the digital rights knowledge of CSOs and movements. RNW Media will also provide capacity strengthening support on media campaigns for social change, which will enable CSOs to use media engagement for changing the civic space and build public awareness.

description.narrative: KI-12 # CSOs/movements, both women and youth led, supported by Masarouna to strengthen their organizational capacities

comment.narrative: A Mutual Capacity Strengthening baseline survey was conducted in 2021, screening partners' organizational capacities and capacities on cross-cutting themes. Capacity strengthening priorities most often indentified by partners are feminist MEAL, safeguarding (response), staff health & care and fundraising. Most partners indicated to already have strong capacity on safeguarding (prevention); project management; project financial management; SRHR foundational knowledge; youth engagement practices; feminist approach to SRHR and SRHR influencing; gender & power analysis; mainstreaming gender justice and social inclusion; transformative leadership; and analyzing & integrating conflict sensitivity. (Organisations could express a need, an offer, or both a need and offer on the same topic).

Capacity strengthening in relation to organizational capacities and capacities on cross-cutting themes will focus on the needs as expressed by respective organisations involved in Masarouna. These include capacity strengthening on feminist MEAL, safeguarding (response), staff health & care, fundraising, and youth engagement practices.

description.narrative: KI-12 # CSOs/movements, not women or youth led, supported by Masarouna to strengthen their organizational capacities

comment.narrative: A Mutual Capacity Strengthening baseline survey was conducted in 2021, screening partners' organizational capacities and capacities on cross-cutting themes. Capacity strengthening priorities most often indentified by partners are feminist MEAL, safeguarding (response), staff health & care and fundraising. Most partners indicated to already have strong capacity on safeguarding (prevention); project management; project financial management; SRHR foundational knowledge; youth engagement practices; feminist approach to SRHR and SRHR influencing; gender & power analysis; mainstreaming gender justice and social inclusion; transformative leadership; and analyzing & integrating conflict sensitivity. (Organisations could express a need, an offer, or both a need and offer on the same topic).

description.narrative: KI-12 # Women led CSOs/ movements supported by Masarouna to strengthen their organizational capacities

comment.narrative: A Mutual Capacity Strengthening baseline survey was conducted in 2021, screening partners' organizational capacities and capacities on cross-cutting themes. Capacity strengthening priorities most often indentified by partners are feminist MEAL, safeguarding (response), staff health & care and fundraising. Most partners indicated to already have strong capacity on safeguarding (prevention); project management; project financial management; SRHR foundational knowledge; youth engagement practices; feminist approach to SRHR and SRHR influencing; gender & power analysis; mainstreaming gender justice and social inclusion; transformative leadership; and analyzing & integrating conflict sensitivity. (Organisations could express a need, an offer, or both a need and offer on the same topic).

Capacity strengthening in relation to organizational capacities and capacities on cross-cutting themes will focus on the needs as expressed by respective organisations involved in Masarouna. These include capacity strengthening on feminist MEAL, safeguarding (response), staff health & care, fundraising, and youth engagement practices.
As a result of close collaboration with RNW Media, the women led partner will have strengthened capacities on PMEAL and finance and project management. RNW Media will support masterclasses on the use of online data collection, analysis and visualisation to partners. In addition, being a member of RNW Media's network, the partner will benefit from network members expertise, be hired as technical experts and/or mutual strengthening of their organizational capacities to implement programmes.

description.narrative: KI-12 # Youth led CSOs/ movements supported by Masarouna to strengthen their organizational capacities
KI-13 # Youth led CSOs/ movements supported by Masarouna to strengthen their civic space influencing capacity
IO 2.2 CSOs and social movements working with young people have adapted to shifting civic space and reclaimed space through movement building and stronger and more innovative alliances.
KI-11a # Cases at all other levels (national/international) where CSOs/movements succeed in creating space for their demands and positions

comment.narrative: Civic space is declining. Human Rights violations towards human right defenders (HRD) and CSO´s happen on various occasions. CSOs, national coalitions and networks work together to reclaim the civic space and to provide a counter narrative on this regard. Online HR violations (especially online GBV and harassment) is reported to be growing and civic space to promote for inclusive SRHR is declining.

All partners will participate in decision making process related to SRHR and people with disabilities (PWD), espcially when it comes to areas of their work and expertise as they have the knowledge about the needs on the ground. What needs to be changed is increased transparency in decision making process, legal reforms, and elections to reactivate the Legislative Council.
RNW Media partners will be able to influence the agenda and decision making processes based on information collected and disseminated through the digital platforms they have developed over the past 5 years.

description.narrative: KI-11a # Cases at subnational level where CSOs/movements succeed in creating space for their demands and positions
LTO 1: Decision-makers have formulated (and implemented where possible) policies, and/or removed/amended harmful policies, to enable young people to enjoy their SRHR.
KI-1a # Governmental policies blocked, adopted and/or improved to enable diverse young people to enjoy their SRHR

comment.narrative: Laws and regulations in general fail to protect women, girls and other marginalized groups. The legal framework further hinders young people's ability to exercise their SRHR rights. Applicable laws, for example, condone Gender Based Violence (GBV). Additionally, the outdated legal framework does not take into account the different needs of marginalized and vulnerable groups in present day times. GBV is a key concern. Child marriage is an increasing phenomenon, with 24% of children getting married beforethe age of 18; a negative coping mechanism associated with poverty, unemployment, and patriarchal and harmful social norms.

Masarouna partners aims at having one governmental policy adopted or improved during the course of the project, to enable diverse young people to claim their SRHR. During Year 2, partners will prioritize which policy will be specifically targeted for advocacy. This decision will be informed by the multiple studies currently conducted. The project aims at enhancing the referral and service provision targetting youth, enhance policy and service provision at government levels and enhance SRHR in relation topeople with disabilities (PWD) among others.

description.narrative: KI-1b # By-laws enabling diverse young people to enjoy their SRHR that are better implemented or enforced

comment.narrative: The National Health Strategy was adopted, which aims to ensure the provision of comprehensive and integrated services for all citizens. However, current health services provided are insufficient. The weak social system lacks integrated healthcare for women, despite the presence of women’s units in Ministries. In rural areas, effects stemming from the lack of services are magnified. Some communities receive irregular mobile clinic health services, forcing women to travel long distances to different towns and cities to access them.

Masarouna partners aims at having one by-law better implemented during the course of the project, to enable diverse young people to claim their SRHR. During Year 2, partners will prioritize which by-law will be specifically targeted for advocacy. This decision will be informed by the multiple studies currently conducted. The project aims at enhancing the referral and service provision targetting youth, enhance policy and service provision at government levels and enhance SRHR in relation to people with disabilities (PWD) among others.

description.narrative: KI-1b # Governmental policies enabling diverse young people to enjoy their SRHR that are better implemented or enforced

comment.narrative: The National Health Strategy was adopted, which aims to ensure the provision of comprehensive and integrated services for all citizens. However, current health services provided are insufficient. The weak social system lacks integrated healthcare for women, despite the presence of women’s units in Ministries. In rural areas, effects stemming from the lack of services are magnified. Some communities receive irregular mobile clinic health services, forcing women to travel long distances to different towns and cities to access them.

Masarouna partners aims at having two governmental policies better implemented during the course of the project, to enable diverse young people to claim their SRHR. During Year 2, partners will prioritize which policies will be specifically targeted for advocacy. This decision will be informed by the multiple studies currently conducted. The project aims at enhancing the referral and service provision targetting youth, enhance policy and service provision at government levels and enhance SRHR in relationto people with disabilities (PWD) among others.

description.narrative: KI-1a # By-laws blocked, adopted and/or improved to enable diverse young people to enjoy their SRHR

LTO2: A stronger, inclusive and transformative civil society movement has contributed to an enabling environment and amplified the voices of young people to claim and exercise their SRHR
KI-9b # Governmental policies affecting NGOs, CSOs and/or labour/trade unions blocked, adopted and/or improved to improve civil society space

comment.narrative: Communities are subjected to violence, intimidation or repression, and authorities and non-state actors sponsor restrictions on the fundamental right of assembly and freedom of expression, especially targeting human rights defenders and their organisations who are key agents for resistance and change. While the occupation authorities continue to monitor and target civil society organizations and seek to dry-up their resources and restrict their movement and operations, the domestic authority has adopted practices to control and minimize the monitoring role of civil society organizations. A series of legislations threaten the existence of CSOs, especially the policy that was suggested by the government for the latter to give pre-approval for receiving funds. This suggested policy was challenged by CSOs and international donors and has not been put into effect until present, yet it comprises a threat and limitation on CSOs work. Another threat is the cybercrime law that gives the government the authority to monitor and block everything in the digital space.
During Year 2, partners will prioritize which policy will be specifically targeted. This decision will be informed by a civic space workshop conducted with them.

description.narrative: KI-9c # By-laws or codes of conducts affecting NGOs, CSOs and/or labour/trade unions that are better implemented or enforced to improve civil society space

comment.narrative: The growing discourse on security and countering terrorism grants the government and security apparatus a strong dominance on the work of CSOs. The occupation authorities' security apparatus controls agendas of CSOs and the type of activities they can conduct. The regulatory framework is complex given the different laws that apply in different areas of the country. A presidential decree regulates the work of CSOs forcing them to submit financial and operational plans at the beginning of the year. This requirement limits their work opportunities and reduces efficiency. Due to pressures by civil society and human rights actors as well as international actors the decree was cancelled for now by another presidential decree. However, it is unclear what might happen in the future. Moreover, certain regulations that apply on tendering and transfer of funds prohibits the transfer of funds, henceforth restricting the work and efficiency of civil society organizations.
During Year 2, partners will prioritize which by-law will be specifically targeted. This decision will be informed by a civic space workshop conducted with them.

description.narrative: KI-9c # Government policies affecting NGOs, CSOs and/or labour/trade unions that are better implemented or enforced to improve civil society space

comment.narrative: The growing discourse on security and countering terrorism grants the government and security apparatus a strong dominance on the work of CSOs. The occupation authorities' security apparatus controls agendas of CSOs and the type of activities they can conduct. The regulatory framework is complex given the different laws that apply in different areas of the country. A presidential decree regulates the work of CSOs forcing them to submit financial and operational plans at the beginning of the year. This requirement limits their work opportunities and reduces efficiency. Due to pressures by civil society and human rights actors as well as international actors the decree was cancelled for now by another presidential decree. However, it is unclear what might happen in the future. Moreover, certain regulations that apply on tendering and transfer of funds prohibits the transfer of funds, henceforth restricting the work and efficiency of civil society organizations.
During Year 2, partners will prioritize which policy will be specifically targeted. This decision will be informed by a civic space workshop conducted with them.

KI-9b # International agreements affecting NGOs, CSOs and/or labour/trade unions blocked, adopted and/or improved to improve civil society space

Partnership indicator
KI-16 # CSOs/movements, both women and youth led, engaged in Masarouna

comment.narrative: Currently, Masarouna has 6 partners in the country. Interventions these organizations work on include lobby and/or advocacy, public campaigning, (social) media work, coalition building, awareness raising, research, capacity strengthening, and piloting projects.

The women and youth led partner organisation enhanced representing the SRHR agenda within their constituencies whereby partners assumed a leading role in establishing and leading on groups that include decision-makers and activists in the field of SRHR.
The Masarouna partnership starts and will evolve during the 1st year of implementation, where partners are working together and providing capacity support to each other

The partnership is expected to be sustained throughout the project, and beyond, as the various partners have complementary roles to each other. It will also be explored whether humanr rights organizations can bring an added value to the partnership.

description.narrative: KI-16 # CSOs/movements, not women or youth led, engaged in Masarouna

comment.narrative: Currently, Masarouna has 6 partners in the country. Interventions these organizations work on include lobby and/or advocacy, public campaigning, (social) media work, coalition building, awareness raising, research, capacity strengthening, and piloting projects.

The not women or youth led partner organisation enhanced representing the SRHR agenda within their constituencies whereby partners assumed a leading role in establishing and leading on groups that include decision-makers and activists in the field of SRHR.
The Masarouna partnership starts and will evolve during the 1st year of implementation, where partners are working together and providing capacity support to each other

The partnership is expected to be sustained throughout the project, and beyond, as the various partners have complementary roles to each other. It will also be explored whether humanr rights organizations can bring an added value to the partnership.

description.narrative: KI-16 # Women led CSOs/movements engaged in Masarouna

comment.narrative: Currently, Masarouna has 6 partners in the country. Interventions these organizations work on include lobby and/or advocacy, public campaigning, (social) media work, coalition building, awareness raising, research, capacity strengthening, and piloting projects. One women led partner is a national organization committed to social development, by addressing educational and counseling needs as they relate to SRHR. The organisation aspires to substantially raise community awareness to SRHR challenges and to create counseling and educational programs that will effectively contribute to individual and family development. By partnering and engaging with various community sectors, and by employing methods that reflect sensitivity to the socio-cultural context,the organisation hopes to effectively change the prevailing stereotypes and practices in society.

The 5 women-led partner organisations have enhanced representing the SRHR agenda within their constituencies whereby partners assumed a leading role in establishing and leading on groups that include decision-makers and activists in the field of SRHR.
In 2021, RNW Media partnered with one of the women led organisations. The partnership contributes to reaching the Masarouna objectives and RNW Media objectives - in line with both partners' theories of change.

The Masarouna partnership starts and will evolve during the 1st year of implementation, where partners are working together and providing capacity support to each other.
In 2021, RNW Media partners with a women-led organization. During the course of the project, the partnership will be strengthened as the partners get to know each other and each other's strengths better. RNW Media would see the partnership evolve through collaboration, joint learning meetings, regular exchanges and possible introduction of new partners, which can be identified through the implementation and assessment of project activities.

The partnership is expected to be sustained throughout the project, and beyond, as the various partners have complementary roles to each other. It will also be explored whether humanr rights organizations can bring an added value to the partnership.
RNW Media has the ambition to expand its partner base with other types of organisations that can help reaching the Masarouna objectives. For example, research inistitutes to change social norms and provide evidence-based information for advocacy. Further, RNW Media aims to explore new ways to promote learning and exchanging expertise among all partners and look for effective ways for partnership building, meeting structures and effective decision making.

description.narrative: KI-16 # Youth led CSOs/movements engaged in Masarouna
Representation indicator
KI-17 # CSOs/movements, both women and youth led, engaged in Masarouna that have enhanced representation of constituencies

comment.narrative:
All partners and Oxfam are involved in providing and promoting SRHR services by engaging with civil society, Government bodies, national and international organzations, working groups and networks
In the Mutual Capacity Strengthening baseline survey conducted in 2021, most organisations expressed an offer on capacity strengthening on youth engagement practices, however a considerable number of organisations also expressed a need for capacity strengthening in this area. For capactity strengthening on perception by & relation with constituencies, there were also some organisations with an offer and some with a need. (Organisations could express a need, an offer, or both a need and offer on the same topic.)

Engaged CSOs aspire at playing a bigger role at national and international levels, leading on policy change in at national level, and becoming experts in their fields at regional level. They want to improve representational role by increasing their influencing capacities and representational skills, in addition to pursuing a consultative status at the UN.

They want to improve representational role by increasing their influencing capacities and representational skills, in addition to pursuing a consultative status at the UN.

All partners and Oxfam are involved in providing and promoting SRHR services by engaging with civil society, Government bodies, national and international organzations, working groups and networks
In the Mutual Capacity Strengthening baseline survey conducted in 2021, most organisations expressed an offer on capacity strengthening on youth engagement practices, however a considerable number of organisations also expressed a need for capacity strengthening in this area. For capactity strengthening on perception by & relation with constituencies, there were also some organisations with an offer and some with a need. (Organisations could express a need, an offer, or both a need and offer on the same topic.)
At the time of the baseline, women led organisatons engaged in the programme do not yet all have a policy on how to meaningfully represent youth in the programme. This will be developed in the course of the programme.

RNW Media will co-create a session on youth engagement together with partners. After the session partners will have a position on how youth' representation can be enhanced and monitored in our programmes. As a result, actions can be developed, such as "youth councils", youth as community moderators in the interventions, etc. Collecting data on youth needs and youth satisfaction through youth themselves will give insights in what way youth is represented in the programme.

Engaged CSOs aspire at playing a bigger role at national and international levels, leading on policy change in at national level, and becoming experts in their fields at regional level. They want to improve representational role by increasing their influencing capacities and representational skills, in addition to pursuing a consultative status at the UN.

description.narrative: KI-17 # Youth led CSOs/movements engaged in Masarouna that have enhanced representation of constituencies
Strengthened and stronger alliances, movements and partnerships, maintain/expand the use of safe civic space.
networks, alliances and movements, representing marginalised individuals and their civil society organisations, are strengthened and equiped to better act in favour of equality and equity.
networks, alliances and movements, representing marginalised individuals and their civil society organisations, are strengthened and equiped to better maintain/expand civic space
